name: Great Dane
healthissues: Bloat, hip issues, heart issues, wobbler disease, merle gene issues
history: Contrary to its name, the Great Dane does not actually originate from Denmark, rather, they actually originated in Germany. Great Danes are a very large breed of dog, there are very few larger than them so keep that in mind before deciding to get one. Due to their size it’s not uncommon for them to be chosen as guard dogs. However, this does not mean they have a bad temper, unlike certain other dog breeds.

name: Siberian Husky
healthissues: Eye and hip issues
history: Siberian Huskies are generally very sociable, friendly, and energetic dogs, they certainly needed to be for their role of sled dogs used in big teams in Siberia. Siberian Huskies popularity truly took off all the way back in 1925 where one man and a group of dogs made a 658 mile journey in a mere five and a half days to deliver medicine. This was such a big deal that the lead dog maintains a statue in Central Park in New York City to this day.

name: Bernese Mountain Dog
healthissues: Elbow, eye, hip, and heart issues
history: This breed is the definition of a gentle giant. Their job in their home of Switzerland was one that should be unsurprising given their size, guarding farms and helping move heavy loads, and they certainly succeeded in that job both there and when they were imported into the US in the early 1900’s.

name: Alaskan Malamute
healthissues: Eye, hip, and polyneuropathy issues
history: The Alaskan Malamute is to the Siberian Husky as a pickup truck is to a sports car. The Malamute is named after an Inuit tribe of similar name and was bred to help move significantly larger loads. Since World War Two this breed of dog has seen a rather heavy drop in population.

name: Akita
healthissues: Eye, hip, and thyroid
history: Akita’s are a rather famous breed in Japan and have quite the history there with the most famous dog in Japan being an Akita and still to this day being quite a famous dog. Interestingly, Hellen Keller is credited with introducing them to the US.

name: Doberman Pinscher
healthissues: Eye, heart, hip, and thyroid issues
history: Quite a famous dog breed for more dangerous lines of work for dogs, this breed was fittingly created by a taxman in Germany who wanted some extra protection for when he went out to do his job.

name: Komondor
healthissues: Bloat, eye, and hip issues
history: This breed certainly has one of the more unique looks among dog breeds. They were created in Hungary initially as sheep dogs or otherwise to guard groups of farm animals.

name: Mastiff
healthissues: Bloat, eye, elbow, heart, and hip issues
history: Specifically the English Mastiff as there are many different breeds of mastiff, this breed was encountered as far back as the days of Julius Caesar when he invaded Britain..

name: Labrador Retriever
healthissues: Obesity
history: Labradors are one of the staple pictures of a friendly, high-energy family dog. You will be hard pressed to find a more friendly breed of dog than this. Of course this also means that you should be ready to be able to deal with all of that energy lest they start to spend that energy on things such as your furniture.

name: Cocker Spaniel
healthissues: Eye and hip issues
history: If you see a short dog with an especially long and fancy coat then odds are you’re looking at a Cocker Spaniel. This breed took off in popularity in the US back in the 40’s and 50’s for both a combination of their unique coat and great attitudes.

name: Brittany
healthissues: Eye and hip issues
history: Just by looking at a Brittany you can tell that it was developed first and foremost as a hunting dog. This was developed by those who lived out in the countryside in France and needed a solid and reliable hunting dog and they maintain this status and success today as well. As such it’s important to remember that the Brittany is not an indoor dog and should be taken outside for exercise regularly.

name: English Setter
healthissues: Ear, hip, and thyroid issues
history: Like the other sporting dogs, the Englisher Setter was developed as a hunter’s assistant. The Setter name comes from what they were designated to do, that is to set. Specifically, they would be taken out to find game birds and would lie down when they had found some.

name: Golden Retriever
healthissues: Eye (juvenile cataracts), elbow, heart, and hip issues
history: One of the iconic faces of friendly and energetic family dogs. The Golden Retriever was initially created in Scotland by a noble who desired a perfect hunting companion.

name: Chesapeake Bay Retriever
healthissues: Elbow, eye, hip, and spine issues
history: This breed is a result of the unique situation of the Chesapeake Bay and hunter's desire for a good bird hunting dog in this area. Due to the the bay getting extremely cold during the winter and the area being a massive draw for many birds, the Chesapeake Bay Retreiver was created.

name: Bracco Italiano
healthissues: Elbow, eye, hip, and kidney issues
history: One of the oldest breeds in Europe, the Bracco Italiano dates back to at least 400 BC. This Italian pointer dog has thusly seen quite a bit of history, including it's own near extinction back in the 19th and 20th centuries. As a result of this breeder ending up combining the two variations of it in order to preserve it in the mid 20th century.

name: Barbet
healthissues: Eye, elbow, and hip issues
history: This breed originated back in France around 500 years ago as a dog meant for hunting water fowl. It nearly went extinct after World War 2 but a selection of breeders have managed to bring it back from the brink.

name: Dalmatian
origin: Unknown, most closely associated with Dalmatia
healthissues: Deafness, allergies, urinary stones
history: Dalmatians are one of those easily recognizable breeds by their famous black and white spotted coat. Dalmatians origin is unknown, this is largely as a result of being very commonly used as coach dogs, not as in coaching or teaching something, but as in guarding coaches/caravans back in the day. Due to this they spread across Europe and earned a variety of different names. Ultimately though the name we most widely use today for Dalmatians is a reference to the region in Europe they were most closely associated with.

name: Bulldog
healthissues: Possible overheating, may see tongue stick out too far with a bluish cast.
history: Bulldogs are an unmistakable breed of dog with a face that shows courage and determination. This stems from the 13th century in England when the ancestors of bulldogs fought a bull in the sport of “bullbaiting”. Bulldogs are also very docile, but it is advised to have bulldogs spend more time in an air-conditioned room during the Summer since their short snouts may force them to breathe more when the weather gets hot and humid.

name: Poodle
healthissues: Hip dysplasia, eye disorders, idiopathic epilepsy, sebaceous adenitis, von Willebrand’s disease, immune-mediated disorders
history: Despite the fact that the poodle is the national dog of France, they actually originated in Germany as duck hunters. Poodles are incredibly smart and their coat allows them to swim very well in the water as well as protecting them from certain things like the cold. Poodles also come in three different size varieties known as Standard, Miniature, and Toy. In France, poodles were known for being excellent entertainers.

name: Keeshond
origin: Unknown, but closely tied to the Netherlands
healthissues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, patellar luxation, hyperparathyroidism
history: The Keeshond breed seems to have some mystery behind it since the exact origin is unclear, although they did serve as guard dogs on Dutch ships, and that there is no clear reason why the breed was named “Keeshond”. These dogs have special markings around their face that make it look like it’s wearing spectacles, this shows that the Keeshond is intelligent to go with his amiable personality.

name: Coton de Tulear
healthissues: Eye problems, hip dysplasia, luxating patellas, spinal disc disease
history: It is believed that the Coton de Tulear breed lived in packs in the wild in Madagascar until they were found by French tourists and brought back to Europe. These dogs are known for being fluffy like cotton and being there to comfort their owners. They are also quite amusing, some dogs in this breed even do vocalizations or walk on their hind legs to amuse their owners.

name: Bichon Frise
healthissues: Allergies, bladder infections, luxating patella, cataracts, early tooth loss and gum infection may occur if dental care is not given.
history: Bichon Frises used to reside with the aristocrats until the French Revolution sent their benefactors to prison and the guillotines. Many of these dogs lived on the streets until street performers took them in and they spent some time performing with them. Unfortunately, the aftermath of both world wars left many Bichon Frises on the streets yet again, until some fanciers found them in the streets of France and Belgium and brought them home, allowing the breed to survive. Bichon Frises are known as one of the greatest personality dogs since they are easily trained, quite intelligent, and very agile. These traits make them perfect show dogs, and they also have a hypoallergenic coat along with their appearance that makes them irresistable.

name: German Shepard
healthissues: Hip and spine issues as well as arthritis
history: Contrary to what they are primarily used for nowadays (police dogs, guard dogs, etc.), they actually originated as a shepherding dog. Since the breed is so recent as well, we even know the specific person who set about creating this breed, one Max von Stephanitz, a German cavalry officer in the 1800’s.

name: Pembroke Welsh Corgi
healthissues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, eye disorders, cardiac issues, degenerative myelopathy, von Willebrand’s disease
history: In the past, King Henry I of Britain invited some of the best weavers from Flanders (now Northern Belgium) to come to southwestern Wales. The weavers brought their dogs with them too and eventually, the dogs were named after the place where they worked, Pembrokeshire. Being cattle herding dogs in the past made corgis very athletic, alert, and fearless, and they enjoy being active with their families.

name: Border Collie
healthissues: Hip dysplasia, progressive renal atrophy, deafness, epilepsy, collie eye anomaly, neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis, trapped neutrophil syndrome
history: During the times of the Roman Empire, the Border Collies emerged when Roman dogs were crossed with dogs that Viking raiders brought with them during Britain’s invasion. Border Collies are considered the greatest herders in the world with their athleticism, energy, and intelligence. Border Collies show their friendly nature around their friends but are rather quiet around strangers.

name: Icelandic Sheepdog
healthissues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, patellar luxation
history: Icelandic Sheepdogs were brought from Norway to Iceland by Norse settlers a long time ago. Icelandic Sheepdogs are a national symbol to Iceland and are also classified as spitzes, they can also come in different colors with white markings and a very friendly face.

name: Bloodhound
healthissues: Gastrointestinal (Hereafter referred to as bloat), eye, skin, and ear issues. Beware of overheating due to the thick coat.
history: Bloodhounds are one of those instantly recognizable breeds with their unmistakable face. They are commonly seen in police departments and the like for their world renowned nose, being able to follow almost any trail and for extended periods of time. They tend towards being much more laid-back and independent than other dogs, certainly nowhere near as energetic as breeds such as the Labrador Retriever. *While the modern Bloodhound can be generally said to have originated out of Western Europe the origin of the breed as a whole is unknown, though it is possible it could have existed as far back as the 3rd century in the Roman Empire.

name: Dachshund
healthissues: Knee and heart issues
history: The stereotype of small dogs being crazy energetic may be untrue with some dog breeds but the Dachsund is not one of them. These very short and very long dogs have an absolutely unmistakable appearance but it is for good reason. They were developed for the exact reason their name suggests as translated from the German it is in, it means Badger Dog and with that context their shape, and aggressiveness, makes a lot more sense.

name: Greyhound
healthissues: Eye, heart, and NDRG1 polyneuropathy disease
history: Don’t be alarmed if the Greyhound looks familiar as if you’ve ever been in a history class that has gone over Egyptian hieroglyphs or watched a history documentary on them you may very well have seen ancient pictures of this dog. As their form may suggest they are fantastic sprinters and were used for catching fast animals.

name: Beagle
healthissues: Eye, hip, heart, and thyroid issues
history: Beagles made their name as general purpose small animal hunters. In this role they received the nickname of foot hound in reference to being able to walk and keep up with them on foot rather than requiring horseback to keep up with as in the case of some larger and faster dogs.

name: Borzoi
healthissues: Eye, heart, and thyroid issues
history: Due to their close association with Russian nobility and the monarchy, this breed was made nearly extinct after the Russian Revolution.

name: Norwegian Elkhound
healthissues: Eye and knee issues
history: Norwegian Elkhounds have a very long history in the Scandinavian region and were used for many different reason, though as the name may suggest they were certainly favored for certain activities.

name: Rhodesian Ridgeback
healthissues: Elbow and hip issues
history: This breed was the creation of both native African breeds and foreign breeds brought by Europeans into Africa. While this breed existed for a long time before it was formally recgonized in the early 20th century, it was only officially standardized in 1922.

name: Basenji
healthissues: Eye, hip, thyroid, and inflammatory bowel disease
history: This is one of the oldest known dog breeds. We have records of this breed going at least as far back as ancient Egypt in largely the same form they retain today.

name: Bull Terrier
healthissues: Kidney and heart issues
history: Bull Terriers have an unfortunate history of being born out of dogfighting rings in England. As a result, while not being particularly large they do tend to be fairly strong for their size. Also, while breeders have largely mellowed out their temper since their creation in the 1800’s it is still not recommended to have them around other dogs. As with everything this is not an absolute, each dog is different after all, but do keep this in mind.

name: Scottish Terrier
healthissues: Knee issues and Von Willebrand’s disease (blood not clotting)
history: The Scottish Terrier is a small but rugged dog that had its origins on the farm hunting small animals. While they can still make great companions just know that they can be more of an issue with other small pets.

name: Border Terrier
healthissues: Eye, heart, hip, and knee issues
history: Border Terriers are close relatives to the Scottish Terrier in most regards, origin, demeanor, and purpose. Where the Border Terrier differentiates itself, besides the obvious difference in appearance, is its popularity back in the 1800’s for use in foxhunting in Britain.

name: Rat Terrier
healthissues: Eye, heart, hip, and knee issues
history: There are actually two distinct types of Rat Terrier, minis and standards, with minis being under 13 inches in height and standards being at or above 13 inches in height. They also were actually created in the USA as farm dogs whose primary, although not only, job was to hunt rats. In addition to this, for a terrier breed they can be relatively friendly to other small animals as well. Of course any dog of any breed can behave well or poorly with other animals but the Rat Terrier does generally have a better disposition than most other terrier breeds.

name: Airedale Terrier
healthissues: Eye. heart, and hip issues
history: This breed originated from working communities in Aire Valley during the industrial revolution. Due to the nature of the way it was created, that being by common people trying to make a better dog breed, many different breeds of dogs went into the creation of it and one can see those traces in it today.

name: American Staffordshire Terrier
healthissues: Eye, heart, hip, and thyroid issues
history: As the name suggests, this breed is an american descendant of the British Staffordshire Terrier and as such shares many similarities.

name: Bedlington Terrier
healthissues: Eye, heart, and knee issues
history: As with many dog breeds that were borne out of 19th century England, this breed was bred for dirty jobs, hunting jobs, and occasionally pitfighting, which might be a bit hard to imagine considering their pretty friendly and fragile appearance that they hold.

name: Kerry Blue Terrier
healthissues: Eye and hip issues
history: Like many other breeds, this one was bred for its use on farmsteads and the like, unlike many of those same breeds this one became on icon

name: Pug
healthissues: Breathing and overheating issues
history: Pugs are a lot of love in a small bundle, something you can thank ancient Chinese emperors for cultivating. Similarly to Labradors, Pugs are a great dog for the family but in a much smaller and more easily handled size.

name: Chihuahua
healthissues: Potential heart problems, eye disease, patellar luxation(loose kneecaps), idiopathic epilepsy
history: The chihuahua is known as one of the oldest dog breeds in America. A pre-Columbian culture known as the Toltecs had a larger, heavier ancestor of the chihuahua known as a Techichi, but these dogs were refined to be smaller and lighter after the Aztecs took over the Toltecs in the 12th century. Chihuahuas are perfect city pets due to their small size, and they are quite confident, clever, loyal, and charming despite their size.

name: Shih Tzu
healthissues: Hip dysplasia, patellar luxation, inflammation from too much exposure to air due when eyelids don’t close correctly.
history: Shih Tzus are some of the most refined, affectionate, and well-groomed breed of dogs known. This stems from Chinese history when Shih Tzu lived in palaces with the emperors, being pampered and sitting in their owner’s lap. The Shih Tzu breed is very affectionate, especially with children, and they prefer to be inside rather than play outside.

name: Silky Terrier
healthissues: Patellar luxation, eye disease
history: The Silky Terrier is often mistaken for an Australian or Yorkshire terrier since the Silky Terriers first emerged when those two breeds (along with other possible terriers brought to Australia) were crossed. The Silky Terrier has a special blue-and-tan glossy coat and is considered very energetic, though a bit more refined than most terriers, but despite that it has “Terrier” in its name it’s actually in the “Toy” group due to its small size.

name: Affenpinscher
healthissues: Luxating patella, heart anomalies, vision problems, hip dysplasia, breathing problems in hot weather
history: The Affenpinscher dog is one of the funniest dogs ever known when spending time with their owners. Their name means “monkey dog” or “ape terriers” in Germany, this could be attributed to the fact that they worked like terriers trying to get rid of rats and mice in Germany, showing their confidence and fearlessness. When entertaining others, their shaggy coat adds a bit of charm to their antics, and sometimes Star Wars fans wonder if these dogs look more like Wookies or Ewoks.

name: Japanese Chin
healthissues: Luxating patellas, cataracts, epilepsy, early-onset heart murmurs
history: Despite the breed being called Japanese Chin, their origins are a mystery, some tales say they could have been introduced by Buddhist monks, Chinese emperors, or European merchants, but it has been confirmed that Japanese nobles were the ones who cultivated them. The Japanese Chin is very noble, quiet, charming, and has an unmistakable appearance, they are also graceful and prefer to spend their time indoors.

name: Pomeranian
healthissues: Luxating patellas, hypothyroidism, collapsing tracheas, congestive heart failure, seizures, alopecia X (black skin disease)
history: Pomeranians are well known as one of the most popular breeds of Toy dogs for their personality and smiling face, and they also have a double coat that can come in many different colors. These dogs were made famous back when Queen Victoria first saw the breed in Florence, Italy and brought some back with her to Britain. Pomeranians are rather intelligent, so they do well when they play games, do tricks, or act as watchdogs.

name: Italian Greyhound
healthissues: PRA, autoimmune problems, Legg-Calves-Perthes disease, hypothyroidism
history: Italian Greyhounds were considered famous companions, especially with royals. However, the events of both world wars nearly wiped all the Italian Greyhounds, but American breeders helped to keep the breed alive. Italian Greyhounds have distinctive boned legs and make great show dogs, but are also very attentive, they also need extra care when it gets colder.
